transcript.text: n chsky was born on December 7th 1928 in
Philadelphia Pennsylvania his
undergraduate and graduate years were
spent at the University of Pennsylvania
where he received his PhD in linguistics
in
1955 from 1951 to 55 he was a junior
fellow at the Harvard University Society
of fellows while a junior fellow he
completed his doctoral dissertation
entitled transformational analysis the
major theoretical viewpoints of the
dissert a appeared in the monograph
syntactic structure published in
1957 this formed part of a more
extensive work The Logical structure of
linguistic Theory circulated in mograph
in 1955 and published in
1975 chonky joined the staff of the
Massachusetts Institute of Technology in
1955 and in 1961 was appointed full
professor in the department of modern
languages and Linguistics now the
department of linguistics and philosophy
from 1966 to 1976 he held the Ferrari P
ward professorship of modern languages
and
Linguistics in 1976 he was appointed
Institute Professor from 1958-59 he was
in Residence at The Institute for
advanced study at Princeton NJ in the
spring of 1969 he delivered the John
Lock lecture at Oxford in January 1970
he delivered the Bertrand Russell
Memorial lecture at Cambridge University
in 197 two the Neu Memorial lecture in
New Delhi and in 1977 the hinga lecture
in lien among many others Professor
chsky has received honorary degrees from
the University of London the University
of Chicago lyola University of Chicago
swathmore College Delhi University Bard
College the University of Massachusetts
the University of Pennsylvania
Georgetown University ammer College
Cambridge University the University of
Buenos Aries McGill University the
universitat Roa Iver jilli tarona
Columbia University the University of
Connecticut school and normal Superior
Pisa the University of Western Ontario
the University of Toronto Harvard
University the University of Kolkata and
Universidad Nasional De Colombia he is a
fellow of the American Academy of Arts
and Sciences and the National Academy of
Science he is also a member number of
other professional and learned Societies
in the United States and abroad and is a
recipient of the distinguished
scientific contribution Award of the
American Psychological Association the
Kyoto prize in basic Sciences the
helmholtz medal the Dorothy Eldridge
Peacemaker award the Ben Franklin medal
in computer and cognitive science and
others chonky has written and lectured
widely on Linguistics philosophy
intellectual history contemporary issues
International Affairs and US foreign
policy y his Works include aspects of
the theory of syntax cartisian
linguistics sound pattern of English
with Mor as Hy language and mind
American power and the new mandarins at
war with Asia for reasons of State peace
in the Middle East Reflections on
language the political economy of Human
Rights volume 1 and two with es Herman
rules and
representations lectures on government
and binding towards a new Cold War
radical priorities faithful triangle
knowledge of language turning the tide
Pirates and Emperors on Power and
ideology language and problems of
knowledge the culture of terrorism
manufacturing consent with es Herman
necessary Illusions deterring democracy
year 5001 rethinking Camelot JFK the
Vietnam War and US political culture
letters from Lexington World orders old
and new the minimalist program powers
and Prospects the common good profit
over people the new military humanism
New Horizons in the study of language
and mind Rogue States a new generation
draws the line 9 to 11 and understanding
power
